scenes.plot_segment: A voiceover announces, "Previously on Grey's Anatomy," followed by a montage of key moments: Meredith Grey and Derek Shepherd’s complicated relationship is highlighted, including their one-night stand and Meredith’s hesitation about dating her boss due to hospital rules. George O’Malley’s unspoken feelings for Meredith are referenced as Cristina Yang teases him, which he awkwardly denies. The issue of workplace hierarchy and the risks of sleeping with a superior are discussed among the interns. Dr. Richard Webber informs Meredith that her mother, Ellis Grey, is experiencing worsening Alzheimer’s disease and urges her to complete the necessary legal paperwork. Brief flashes show personal and professional tensions: Izzie Stevens is mentioned in the context of romantic attraction, but George insists she isn’t the one he likes; Meredith’s name comes up as the real focus of his feelings. There are snippets of conversations about being stood up for tequila, a request to move a car, and the interns navigating the challenges of their relationships and responsibilities at Seattle Grace Hospital.

Meredith Grey narrates about Benjamin Franklin’s advice not to put off tasks, connecting procrastination to fear—fear of failure, pain, and rejection. In the hospital locker room, Meredith, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev wait for Dr. Miranda Bailey, who is late. Cristina teases George about his crush on Meredith, joking about whether he wants to ask her out, which George awkwardly denies. Alex makes a sarcastic remark about not being Meredith’s boyfriend yet, and the group debates whether they should wait for Bailey or get started. Meredith’s narration continues, reflecting on the fear of making decisions and mistakes, as the interns prepare for the challenges of the day ahead.

Meredith Grey arrives late to the hospital locker room, where Derek Shepherd is waiting for her. Derek points out that she’s not just late, but also avoiding him. Meredith admits both, acknowledging the tension between them after Bailey caught them together. They briefly discuss whether to talk about what happened with Dr. Miranda Bailey, with Meredith expressing discomfort about being seen as the intern sleeping with the attending and worrying that Bailey is now ignoring her. Derek admits that if he were a better man, he’d end things to make it easier for her, and asks if that’s what she wants. Meredith hesitates, unsure of what she wants. She leaves, saying she’s late for rounds, and Derek tells her to take her time and think about it.

Meredith Grey and Cristina Yang walk briskly through the hospital corridors, both running late for rounds. Meredith anxiously asks Cristina if Dr. Miranda Bailey has told anyone about her relationship with Derek Shepherd, worried about the consequences if their secret gets out. Cristina reassures Meredith that Bailey hasn’t said anything, but bluntly warns her that if the affair is discovered, Derek could face serious professional repercussions, and Meredith’s reputation would suffer. Meredith, feeling the pressure, insists she needs to end things with Derek. Cristina, unimpressed, tells Meredith to stop complaining and points out that nothing good can come from sleeping with an attending. As they reach the nurses’ station, Bailey appears, sternly noting that both Meredith and Cristina are late, and orders them to get moving.

Dr. Miranda Bailey gathers the interns—Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev—outside a patient’s room, instructing them to maintain professionalism and not react to what they see inside. The group enters and greets Annie Connors, a 43-year-old woman with a massive abdominal tumor visibly distending her abdomen. Annie jokes about her age and weight, preferring to be called by her first name. Dr. Preston Burke joins them as the attending surgeon. Alex Karev presents Annie’s case, explaining that the tumor is pressing on her diaphragm and she is scheduled for a CT scan. Annie flirts with Alex, requesting that he be the one to take her for the scan because she finds him attractive. Bailey assigns Izzie to take Annie to radiology, but Annie insists on Alex, and Bailey relents. After leaving the room, the interns discuss the extraordinary size of Annie’s tumor and speculate about its weight, marveling at the uniqueness of the case and noting Alex’s unexpectedly kind demeanor with Annie.

Dr. Miranda Bailey gathers the interns—Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev—and informs them that Annie Connors’s upcoming surgery will require most of the hospital’s surgical staff, so the interns must be extra diligent with the remaining patients and avoid any mistakes. Cristina immediately voices her eagerness to participate in Annie’s surgery, but Bailey tells her not to get her hopes up. Bailey assigns Meredith to locate Annie’s mother and collect a detailed family medical history. As Bailey finishes giving instructions, a trauma code is announced over the intercom. Cristina tries to press Bailey for more information about the surgery, but Bailey curtly reminds her that she doesn’t want to hear any more questions, and the group quickly disperses to their assignments.

Meredith presents Mr. Harper’s post-coronary bypass case to Dr. Miranda Bailey, explaining that his blood pressure was low overnight but stabilized with medication, and that his chest tube output has stopped. Meredith recommends ordering a chest X-ray and checking the chest tube for possible occlusion. Dr. Bailey approves Meredith’s plan, commends her thoroughness, and reassures her that Mr. Harper is currently stable.

George O’Malley, feeling self-conscious after being teased by Cristina Yang about his supposed crush on Meredith Grey, insists to the group of interns—including Cristina, Izzie Stevens, and Alex Karev—that he does not have romantic feelings for Meredith. He asks them not to mention anything to Meredith to avoid making things awkward since they live together. Cristina, unimpressed, tells George to stop talking about it.

Dr. Miranda Bailey leads Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev into Mr. LaVangie’s hospital room. George presents Mr. LaVangie, a 63-year-old man with advanced Parkinson’s disease admitted for pain management due to severe dyskinesia and spinal pain. Meredith suggests an intraspinal catheter for pain control, which Bailey approves, assigning Meredith to prep Mr. LaVangie for the procedure and assist during it. As Bailey gives instructions, the interns listen attentively, and Mr. LaVangie’s daughter asks Meredith if her father is a candidate for deep brain stimulation surgery. Meredith promises to look into it, empathizing with the daughter’s concern for her father. Bailey moves the group along to their next patient, leaving Meredith to begin preparations for Mr. LaVangie’s procedure.

Dr. Miranda Bailey privately confronts Dr. Derek Shepherd, warning him not to show any favoritism toward Meredith Grey because of their personal relationship. Bailey makes it clear that if she observes any special treatment, she will keep Meredith out of the operating room for a month. She assures Derek that she will not reveal their relationship to others but insists that he must treat Meredith the same as any other intern, emphasizing the importance of fairness and professionalism. Derek tries to defend Meredith’s abilities, but Bailey remains firm, making her expectations unmistakably clear.

Izzie prepares Annie Connors for her CT scan, while Alex Karev stands nearby, having been specifically requested by Annie. Izzie reassures Annie that there is a microphone inside the scanner if she feels scared, and Annie insists she’ll be fine. Alex promises to stay close. Annie is gently moved into the CT scanner as Alex and Izzie observe, with the rest of the interns watching from outside the room.

Cristina Yang and Izzie Stevens stand with Alex Karev in the radiology suite, studying Annie Connors’ abdominal CT scan on the monitor. They’re taken aback by the sheer size of the tumor, with Cristina remarking in disbelief about how someone could ignore such a massive growth for so long. Izzie wonders aloud if Annie was simply too afraid to see a doctor, while Alex, less sympathetic, bluntly calls Annie “warped” for letting it get this bad. The interns exchange uneasy glances, their curiosity mixed with judgment as they try to make sense of Annie’s choices.

In Annie Connors’ hospital room, Annie’s mother explains to Dr. Miranda Bailey and the interns—Cristina Yang and Izzie Stevens—that at first, the family thought Annie was simply gaining weight, but as her abdomen continued to grow, they realized something was wrong. Annie confesses she was terrified of hospitals because she lost loved ones who never came home after being admitted, so she avoided seeing a doctor even as the tumor became impossible to ignore. Her mother adds that Annie only began to feel seriously ill the previous night when she struggled to breathe, which finally prompted her to call 911. The interns listen, recognizing how Annie’s fear and avoidance allowed the tumor to grow unchecked for over a year.

Meredith checks on Mr. LaVangie, a Parkinson’s patient admitted for pain management, and is approached by his daughter, who asks if her father could be a candidate for deep brain stimulation surgery. She explains that her wedding is approaching and she wants her father to be well enough to attend. Meredith empathizes, sharing that she understands what it’s like to have a sick parent, and promises to speak with Dr. Shepherd about the possibility of surgery, offering hope to the daughter.

Dr. Preston Burke leads a surgical consult with Dr. Miranda Bailey, Derek Shepherd, and the interns—Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev—to review Annie Connors’ CT results. The scans reveal that Annie’s massive abdominal tumor is compressing her lung and has invaded her spinal canal, making surgery extremely high-risk. The surgeons debate possible approaches, with Burke emphasizing the dangers of paralysis and death. Cristina advocates for an aggressive surgical plan, while Derek points out the likelihood of catastrophic complications. During the discussion, Alex questions whether Annie’s long delay in seeking treatment means she truly wants to live, prompting Izzie to defend Annie by arguing that people take risks every day and that, at only 43, Annie deserves a chance. Bailey mediates the debate, reminding the team to focus on the patient’s wishes and the ethical implications. The group ultimately agrees to present the risks and options to Annie and her family before making a final decision.

Meredith approaches Dr. Derek Shepherd to ask about Mr. LaVangie’s eligibility for deep brain stimulation (DBS) surgery, mentioning that his daughter is eager for options. Derek confirms that Mr. LaVangie is a good candidate for DBS but explains that the patient has declined the procedure, not wanting to risk brain surgery. Meredith suggests they should try to persuade Mr. LaVangie to reconsider, but Derek firmly refuses, emphasizing that they must respect the patient’s wishes. When Meredith continues to question his decision, Derek removes her from Mr. LaVangie’s case for challenging his authority, leaving Meredith frustrated and sidelined.

Dr. Miranda Bailey meets with Annie Connors and her mother to discuss the upcoming surgery to remove Annie’s massive abdominal tumor, carefully outlining the significant risks involved. Annie’s mother insists that Annie will have the operation, but Annie refuses to consent unless Alex Karev is excluded from the procedure, having overheard Alex make insensitive remarks about her during the CT scan via a live microphone. Bailey listens to Annie’s concerns, acknowledges Alex’s mistake, and agrees to her condition, informing Annie and her mother that Alex will be banned from the operating room for the week. Bailey later confronts Alex about his unprofessional behavior, making it clear that his actions have consequences and that he is not to participate in Annie’s surgery.

Izzie Stevens prepares Annie Connors for surgery, drawing her blood and offering reassurance as Annie anxiously waits. Annie, self-deprecating, calls herself the “fat, nasty tumor lady” and insists she doesn’t deserve anyone’s sympathy. Izzie gently asks why Annie waited so long to seek help. Annie admits she avoided hospitals because everyone she knew who went in never came out, revealing her deep-seated fear. Izzie empathizes, sharing that she also puts things off—like telling her roommate about her feelings—drawing a parallel between her own avoidance and Annie’s. Annie responds with a wry joke, lightening the mood between them.

Cristina vents to Dr. Bailey about feeling sidelined because of Meredith’s relationship with Dr. Shepherd, insisting she’s missing out on surgical opportunities. Bailey firmly tells Cristina that Meredith has earned her place and warns her not to blame Meredith for her own frustrations. Meanwhile, Meredith confides in Cristina that she needs to end things with Derek, worried that their relationship is affecting her reputation and the group. Izzie approaches Cristina, eager to scrub in on Annie Connors’ surgery, but Cristina asserts her claim, having already spoken to Bailey. The interns gather in the lounge, joking about Dr. Burke possibly having a crush on Cristina, while Alex tries to join the conversation but is brushed off by the others.

Cristina vents to Meredith, Izzie, George, and Alex about being reprimanded by Dr. Shepherd, calling him a jackass. Alex disagrees, insisting that Dr. Shepherd is actually a great surgeon and mentor. The group commiserates about the stress and disappointments of their day, with George suggesting they all go out for drinks to unwind. Izzie hands George a drink, leading to a brief, awkward exchange between them as they navigate the tension and camaraderie within the group.

Meredith checks on Mr. LaVangie, who continues to refuse deep brain stimulation surgery for his Parkinson’s disease. His daughter, visibly upset, pleads with him to reconsider, emphasizing how much she needs him. Mr. LaVangie insists that the decision is his alone, asserting his right to choose. Meredith gently challenges him, pointing out that his choice affects his daughter’s life as well, and asks him to consider undergoing the surgery for her sake.

In the operating room, Dr. Preston Burke leads the surgical team as they prepare for Annie Connors’ complex tumor resection. Dr. Miranda Bailey warns the interns—Cristina Yang, George O’Malley, and Meredith Grey—that retracting Annie’s massive abdominal tumor will be physically exhausting and require teamwork. As the team scrubs in and positions Annie, Bailey emphasizes the importance of maintaining focus due to the high risk of complications. Meanwhile, outside the OR, Meredith finds Dr. Derek Shepherd and informs him that Mr. LaVangie has agreed to undergo deep brain stimulation surgery, but only if it happens that day. Derek acknowledges Meredith’s update and immediately begins preparing for the DBS procedure, coordinating with Bailey and the neurosurgical team to ensure everything is ready for surgery.

Dr. Miranda Bailey pulls Meredith Grey aside to address her ongoing relationship with Dr. Derek Shepherd. Bailey makes it clear that she is not interested in the personal details but is deeply concerned about the impact their relationship is having on the work environment and the other surgical interns. She warns Meredith that her actions are affecting the entire group, emphasizing that any perception of favoritism or unprofessional behavior could have serious consequences for everyone involved. Bailey insists that Meredith must consider the repercussions of her choices, both for herself and for her fellow interns, and cautions her to maintain strict professionalism moving forward.

George O’Malley and Alex Karev are assigned to routine, less desirable tasks while the other interns participate in surgeries. George complains about being left out of the action, feeling overlooked compared to the others. Alex, unfazed, jokes about doing his work in the stairwell to avoid Bailey’s scrutiny. They exchange a few words about their luck, then split up to handle their respective assignments.

In the operating room, Dr. Burke leads the surgical team as Cristina Yang, Meredith Grey, and George O’Malley assist with Annie Connors’ tumor resection. The team quickly realizes the tumor is even larger and more vascular than anticipated, prompting Dr. Burke to request additional blood units and warn everyone about the heightened risk of hemorrhage. Cristina efficiently manages the suction and communicates with Dr. Burke about the tumor’s margins, while Meredith helps monitor Annie’s vitals. George, tasked with retracting the tumor, loses focus momentarily, prompting Dr. Burke to sharply remind him to stay alert and maintain steady hands. The tension in the OR rises as the surgeons work together to control the bleeding and carefully navigate the complex anatomy, aware that Annie’s life hangs in the balance.

Dr. Derek Shepherd performs the deep brain stimulation (DBS) procedure on Mr. LaVangie, who remains awake during the surgery. Dr. Miranda Bailey assists, while Izzie Stevens stands by to reassure and encourage the patient, helping him stay calm and cooperative. Derek carefully drills into Mr. LaVangie’s skull and uses neurological testing to locate the precise area in the brain to target. Mr. LaVangie, nervous but lucid, jokes with Izzie to ease the tension. The team successfully completes the procedure, and Mr. LaVangie shows immediate improvement, confirming the surgery’s effectiveness.

Izzie Stevens is interrupted while assisting with Mr. LaVangie’s DBS procedure when she’s urgently called to check on another patient. She asks Nurse Tyler to page Alex Karev again, frustrated that Alex still hasn’t responded to her previous requests. Nurse Tyler assures her that Alex has already been paged, but Izzie insists, emphasizing the importance of reaching him.

In the operating room, Dr. Preston Burke leads the surgical team as they work to remove Annie Connors’ massive abdominal tumor. Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, and George O’Malley assist, each visibly fatigued by the length and difficulty of the procedure. As they carefully dissect around the tumor, Dr. Burke and Cristina are startled by the size of a major artery supplying blood to the mass. The unexpected bleeding quickly becomes severe, prompting Dr. Burke to urgently request more units of O negative blood from the circulating nurse. With the situation escalating, Dr. Burke instructs George to step in and apply direct pressure to the bleeding vessel to help control the hemorrhage. The team works in tense coordination, racing to stabilize Annie as her blood loss intensifies.

Meredith Grey confronts Derek Shepherd about the perception that she is receiving special treatment because of their personal relationship. Meredith asserts her independence, insisting she does not want or need any favors, and emphasizes her ability to handle herself professionally. Derek acknowledges her concerns, assuring her that he values her skills as a surgeon and will not give her preferential treatment. Their conversation is tense but honest, highlighting the strain their relationship is placing on Meredith’s reputation among the interns.

Cristina Yang approaches Derek Shepherd to apologize for previously calling him a jackass. Derek responds with humor, telling Cristina that if Meredith Grey doesn’t marry him, he will marry Cristina instead. Both share a laugh, and the atmosphere between them is light and playful, easing any lingering tension.

Mr. Harper, recovering from coronary bypass surgery, suddenly deteriorates as his blood pressure plummets and he develops a life-threatening arrhythmia. Izzie Stevens and Cristina Yang are at his bedside when the crisis unfolds. With no attending immediately available and recognizing signs of cardiac tamponade, Cristina urgently instructs Izzie to perform an emergency bedside thoracotomy, despite Izzie’s lack of experience with the procedure. Cristina talks Izzie through each step, guiding her to open Mr. Harper’s chest, locate and remove a large blood clot compressing the heart, and manually massage the heart until a pulse returns. Working together under intense pressure, the two interns manage to stabilize Mr. Harper, saving his life.

Dr. Preston Burke leads the surgical team—assisted by Cristina Yang, Meredith Grey, and George O’Malley—in the operating room as they attempt to remove Annie Connors’s massive abdominal tumor. The surgery quickly becomes complicated by severe blood loss, with the team struggling to control the bleeding and maintain Annie’s stability. Dr. Burke orders additional units of blood, while George helps by applying direct pressure to the bleeding vessels. Cristina and Meredith work urgently to assist Burke, passing instruments and suctioning blood as the situation grows increasingly dire. Despite their coordinated efforts and repeated attempts to stem the hemorrhage, Annie’s blood pressure continues to drop. The team exchanges tense glances as the monitors sound alarms, and Burke calls for more aggressive measures, but Annie’s condition deteriorates rapidly. Ultimately, despite the team’s best efforts, Annie goes into cardiac arrest and cannot be revived. The room falls silent as Burke calls the time of death, and the interns stand in stunned silence, visibly shaken by the loss.

Dr. Burke calls the time of death as Annie Connors dies on the operating table, surrounded by Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, and George O’Malley, who stand in stunned silence after their efforts to save her fail.

Meredith narrates about the lessons learned from experience and the importance of seizing the moment, referencing proverbs about time and action. In the aftermath of Annie Connors’ death in surgery, Izzie Stevens apologizes to Dr. Burke for losing the patient, but Burke reassures her, emphasizing that she and Cristina saved Mr. Harper’s life with their emergency intervention. Meredith’s voiceover continues, reflecting on how taking action, even when difficult, leads to growth and understanding.

Cristina Yang confronts Dr. Preston Burke in the on-call room, telling him she won’t cover for him anymore or do him any more favors, frustrated by the physical exhaustion from Annie Connors’ surgery and upset over Annie’s death. Burke asks Cristina what their relationship actually is, seeking clarity. Cristina, deflecting, questions whether he truly wants a definition. After a charged pause, Cristina tells Burke to lock the door, signaling her desire for intimacy despite their unresolved issues.

Alex Karev enters the interns’ lounge and asks if anyone has seen Meredith Grey. Cristina Yang, picking up on Alex’s interest, smirks and tells him that Meredith is “off the market.” George O’Malley, flustered by the implication, quickly insists that he and Meredith are just friends and that he would know if she were seeing someone. Izzie Stevens teases George about his obvious crush, while Cristina continues to needle him, making George even more defensive as he tries to downplay his feelings for Meredith in front of the group.

Meredith narrates about the importance of taking action instead of being paralyzed by uncertainty, emphasizing that trying and failing is better than never trying at all. After a long, emotionally taxing day, Meredith and Derek meet outside the hospital. Derek invites Meredith to a spot where they can watch the sunrise over the ferry boats, recalling a detail she once shared about her love for ferry boats. Meredith quietly admits she has a thing for them, and Derek remembers, deepening their connection. As they stand together, Meredith’s voiceover reflects on the courage it takes to act despite fear, and how even failure is preferable to endless wondering. Derek softly says, “Thank you,” acknowledging the significance of their moment.
